author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: MoMA PS1 Looks to Los Angeles for New Director
description: The Long Island City contemporary art museum has chosen a veteran curator as its leader: Connie Butler of the Hammer Museum.
content: Marking an important appointment in the contemporary art world, Connie Butler of the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles has been named the next director of MoMA PS1, which since 1971 has focused on experimental contemporary art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: The Connection Between Seasonal Allergies and Mental Health
description: Studies suggest that allergens could play a role in mood disorders like depression and anxiety. Here’s what to know and how to get help if you need it.
content: Seasonal allergies can be miserable. The sneezing, congestion and itchy, watery eyes can feel like a terrible cold that won’t go away, especially now that pollen seasons are getting longer and more intense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: efficiency
description: This word has appeared in 450 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word efficiency has appeared in 450 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 2 in “An Aggressive Passive Push for a Brooklyn Brownstone” by Stephen Wallis:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Rhiannon Giddens and Michael Abels Win the Pulitzer Prize for Music
description: Giddens said that the success of their opera “Omar” proves that “nobody has the lock on being a composer.”
content: “I mean, look: I’m bowled over right now,” the polymathic musician Rhiannon Giddens said from her home in Ireland on Monday, shortly after winning the Pulitzer Prize for music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Born of Grief, a Couple’s Off Broadway Incubator Marks 20 Years
description: Even as it celebrates with a gala, the Ars Nova family now faces another challenge as one of its founders confronts A.L.S.
content: In 2002, Jenny and Jon Steingart founded the Off Broadway incubator Ars Nova as a way of honoring Jenny’s brother, Gabriel Wiener, who in 1997 died of a brain aneurysm at the age of 26. Now, as the nonprofit theater is marking its 20th anniversary, the couple is facing another wrenching struggle: Jon has A.L.S., the severe neurological disorder also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of May 1, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: Imagine if Another Bernie Sanders Challenges Joe Biden
description: Someone could do for foreign policy what Sanders did for domestic policy.
content: To understand why progressives should challenge Joe Biden in the upcoming Democratic presidential primary, remember what happened during the last one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Shift, Texas House Advances Bill to Raise Age to Buy Assault Weapons
description: The mass shooting at a shopping center in Allen, Texas, has exerted an unexpectedly raw and emotional force on the State Legislature.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — What had for years been a solid wall of opposition among Texas Republicans to gun control showed small signs of cracking on Monday as a bipartisan committee of the State Legislature voted to advance a bill raising the minimum age to purchase AR-15-style rifles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: ‘Succession’ Style, Episode 7: Snakes and Scorpions
description: Matsson crashes the election eve party, and Shiv and Tom come to blows.
content: This article contains spoilers for Episode 7 of the final season of “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Justin Porter
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Texas Reels From Mass Shootings
description: Also, evacuation orders in occupied Ukraine.
content: Thirteen people have been killed in mass shootings in Texas in the past two weeks. The mass murders have fueled a new openness to gun regulation among some Texans, but Republican lawmakers have shown no interest in taking action to address the violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Homemade, Cheap and Lethal, Attack Drones Are Vital to Ukraine
description: Fighting superior Russian firepower, Ukrainian forces turn off-the-shelf drones into deadly weapons by adapting them to carry explosives.
content: Buzzing like an oversize mosquito, a small drone lifted off from a farm field in eastern Ukraine, hovered for a bit, then raced toward Russian positions near the battle-ravaged city of Bakhmut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Brain Drain Threatens the F.D.I.C. and Its Efforts to Regulate Banks
description: High turnover and low pay are luring its staff to the private sector, leaving the banking supervisor, and the financial system, more vulnerable to a crisis.
content: For the last three years, Hannah Johnson worked on a New York team of bank examiners at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, assessing the health of banks in the region and looking for potential red flags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Things in Russia Aren’t as Bad as the Bad Old Soviet Days. ‘They’re Worse.’
description: Vladimir Putin has made himself the personal embodiment of the Russian state.
content: It has become commonplace to perceive Vladimir Putin as reverting to Soviet ways. So it seemed natural, shortly after the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich was arrested in Russia, that when I ran into a woman I’d known in Moscow back in the Soviet days, I lamented that things were more and more as they had been in those bad old days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: How Can We Bring an End to the ‘Epidemic of Loneliness’?
description: At any moment, about one out of every two Americans feels lonely. How can we help one another feel more connected?
content: Dr. Vivek H. Murthy is the surgeon general of the United States. As “the nation’s doctor,” it is his job to protect and improve the health and safety of the American people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Currents of change in Britain.
content: On Thursday, elections for Britain’s local officials. On Saturday, King Charles III’s coronation. As milestones go, the two could hardly have had less in common, yet each, in its own way, confirmed a Britain on the cusp of change, in both politics and the monarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Ukraine War Coverage Earns Pulitzers for The A.P. and The Times
description: Several news organizations won multiple awards, including The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times and AL.com, a site that covers Alabama.
content: Coverage of the war in Ukraine dominated the Pulitzer Prizes on Monday, with The Associated Press winning two awards for its reporting and photography, including the prestigious public service prize, and The New York Times winning for a mix of news and investigative articles about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Driver Whose S.U.V. Struck and Killed Migrants in Texas Is Charged
description: The authorities in Brownsville, Texas, said that George Alvarez was behind the wheel and that they were still trying to determine whether the crash was deliberate.
content: BROWNSVILLE, Texas — At first Yohonny Miratriz heard a deafening roar as he and two friends walked on Sunday morning near the shelter where they had spent the night before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Christophers
title: Why Are We Allowing the Private Sector to Take Over Our Public Works?
description: The Inflation Reduction Act will spur the takeover of our infrastructure by private entities, particularly large global asset managers, with likely negative consequences.
content: The Inflation Reduction Act will reshape the physical and economic landscape of the United States over the next decade, including in ways that might surprise a lot of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Faingnaert and Anna Hart
title: Flamenco and Fervor: Inside Spain’s El Rocío Pilgrimage
description: The annual spectacle, featuring fanciful caravans and riders on horseback, and is arguably the most potent visual representation of Andalusian culture.
content: “You can’t wear that flamenco dress for the El Rocío pilgrimage, Bonita,” Maria Cárdenas, our Airbnb host, said with a laugh. “You’ll die in the heat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Waffles or Pancakes?
description: You (or mom) might just want both, so you don’t have to decide between chocolate waffles and cornmeal blueberry pancakes.
content: With Mother’s Day fast approaching, it’s time to ask yourself: Is the mom in your life on team waffles or pancakes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Stanley Deser, Whose Ideas on Gravity Help Explain the Universe, Dies at 92
description: His theory of supergravity sought to bridge quantum mechanics and general relativity, a potential step toward a theory of everything.
content: Stanley Deser, a theoretical physicist who helped illuminate the details of gravity and how it shapes the space-time fabric of the universe, died on April 21 in Pasadena, Calif. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Anushka Patil
title: Victory Day, the battle for Bakhmut, and NATO: What to watch for this week.
description: Russia will celebrate its most important annual military holiday this week, amid mounting anxiety following a series of attacks and over a looming Ukrainian counteroffensive.
content: Russia will celebrate its most important annual military holiday this week, amid mounting anxiety following a series of attacks and over a looming Ukrainian counteroffensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Phoenix to Start Clearing Sprawling Downtown Homeless Encampment
description: A Phoenix judge ordered the city to begin clearing tents in the Zone, an area that has as many as 1,100 people sleeping unsheltered on a given night.
content: Phoenix officials will begin clearing one of the nation’s largest homeless encampments this week in a downtown area known as the Zone, where neighbors and business owners have filed a lawsuit calling the tent community “a great humanitarian crisis” because of open drug use, violence and property damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Timothy McVeigh’s Dreams Are Coming True
description: Republican gun fetishism has forced us to normalize mass shootings.
content: This column has been updated to reflect news developments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Mass Shootings Become Almost Daily Events
description: Readers renew calls for gun control after a gunman kills eight at a Texas mall. Also: The coronation; horse racing; Guantánamo; religion in court.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mary Wilson, Rob Szypko, Nina Feldman, Will Reid, Clare Toeniskoetter, Rachel Quester, Lisa Chow, Marc Georges, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: A Crisis of Ethics at the Supreme Court
description: Allegations of misconduct have brought calls for tighter rules on the justices on the nation’s highest court.
content: Debate about ethical standards for Supreme Court justices has intensified after a series of revelations about undisclosed gifts, luxury travel and property deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Sam Now’ and ‘Jeopardy! Masters’
description: A coming-of-age documentary from PBS follows Sam Harkness and his family over 25 years, and a new iteration of the popular quiz show premieres on ABC.
content: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 8-14. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Grace Bumbry, Barrier-Shattering Opera Diva, Is Dead at 86
description: A flamboyant mezzo-soprano (who could also sing meaty soprano roles), she overcame racial prejudice to become one of opera’s first, and biggest, Black stars.
content: Grace Bumbry, a barrier-shattering mezzo-soprano whose vast vocal range and transcendent stage presence made her a towering figure in opera and one of its first, and biggest, Black stars, died on Sunday in Vienna. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Vida Blue Was a Baseball Comet
description: From the first time teammates, opponents, coaches and fans saw him, they knew Blue was a star. And they wanted to see more.
content: The bright lights would come soon enough. On that May night in 1970, at the old ballpark at the confluence of the Des Moines and the Raccoon Rivers, they were dimmer than the lights in the big leagues. Tony La Russa knew that much, because he’d been there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Theodor Diener, Who Discovered the Tiniest of Infectious Agents, Dies at 102
description: The cause of a potato disease bedeviled scientists for decades before Dr. Diener figured out that an impossibly small pathogen called a viroid was to blame.
content: Finding something infinitesimally tiny is never easy. But it’s much harder when the searcher doesn’t know what to look for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russia launched a large wave of attack drones over Kyiv, Ukrainian officials say.
description: Ukraine’s military said that it shot down all of the drones, in what was the fourth large-scale assault aimed at the city this month.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia attacked Kyiv with nearly three dozen drones overnight, Ukrainian officials said on Monday, one of the largest waves to directly target the Ukrainian capital and part of a broader aerial assault on towns and cities across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Cowardice of the Deficit Scolds
description: Why “responsible” organizations are enabling G.O.P. extortion.
content: Financial markets are finally taking notice of the possibility that the United States may soon default on its debts. Interest rates on short-term debt and the cost of insuring against default have spiked, reflecting fears that U.S. debt won’t be repaid on time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: ‘Catastrophic’ Congo Flooding Kills More Than 400 People
description: Days after the flooding began, survivors are still pulling victims from the rubble and mud, and thousands have been left homeless. More rain is likely in the coming days.
content: The death toll of last week’s deadly floods and landslides in the Democratic Republic of Congo climbed to more than 400 people, the government said on Monday, as rescue workers and family members searched through debris and mud for victims and survivors of the disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Baek
title: Two Creative Directors on Sports, Hip-Hop and Faith
description: Free Richardson, of the Compound, and Phil Cho, of NoLedge Productions, have become innovators in the world of marketing. They also consider themselves family.
content: The birth of the partnership between the creative directors Free Richardson and Phil Cho hinged on, of all things, their shared faith. In 2018, Mr. Cho, the founder of NoLedge Productions, pitched a collaboration between his company and Mr. Richardson’s creative agency the Compound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Alexandra Berzon
title: Under the Radar, Right-Wing Push to Tighten Voting Laws Persists
description: The clashes in state capitals have faded, but the Republican push for stricter state election laws is organized and planning for the long term.
content: The first recent wave of legislation tightening voting laws came in 2021, when Donald J. Trump’s false claims of voter fraud spurred Republican lawmakers to act over loud objections from Democrats. Two years later, a second wave is steadily moving ahead, but largely under the radar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Wildfires Burn Nearly 1 Million Acres in Western Canada
description: Light rain and cooler temperatures brought much-needed relief over the weekend to Alberta, where nearly 30,000 residents have been forced to evacuate.
content: A shift in weather conditions brought much-needed relief to firefighters in Western Canada, where around 964,000 acres have burned since wildfires started more than a week ago, destroying dozens of structures and forcing nearly 30,000 residents of Alberta to evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lorne Manly
title: Yogi Berra on the Field: The Case for Baseball Greatness
description: A new documentary argues that the Yankee catcher was not just a malaprop-prone, beloved celebrity but also a legend of the game.
content: In the latest edition of Bartlett’s Familiar Quotations, there’s a sports figure who towers over the competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib, Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Pulitzer Prizes 2023: A Guide to the Winning Books and Finalists
description: Hernan Diaz and Barbara Kingsolver each received a fiction prize, and the Washington Post journalists Robert Samuels and Toluse Olorunnipa won the nonfiction prize for “His Name is George Floyd.”
content: Nineteen books were recognized as winners or finalists for the Pulitzer Prize on Monday, in the categories of general history, biography, poetry, general nonfiction and fiction, which — in a surprise — had two winners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: In Norway, the Electric Vehicle Future Has Already Arrived
description: About 80 percent of new cars sold in Norway are battery-powered. As a result, the air is cleaner, the streets are quieter and the grid hasn’t collapsed. But problems with unreliable chargers persist.
content: BAMBLE, Norway — About 110 miles south of Oslo, along a highway lined with pine and birch trees, a shiny fueling station offers a glimpse of a future where electric vehicles rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calla Kessler and Desiree Rios
title: Behind the Scenes at the Westminster Dog Show
description: The annual event comes back to New York City this year, with best in show being decided at Arthur Ashe Stadium in Flushing.
content: It still isn’t Madison Square Garden, but at least the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show is back in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: On ‘Succession,’ Marriage Reveals Its Sting
description: Marriage is where the HBO series “Succession” hits viewers the closest.
content: Scorpions are dreaded and reviled for good reason. A remarkably aggressive predator, the scorpion has a bad habit of killing and feeding on its young. And when it comes to love, scorpion mating is one of “the nastiest affairs in nature”:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.2 Million Homes in California
description: A two-unit Edwardian house in San Francisco, a midcentury-modern home in Beverly Hills and a 2018 retreat in Danville.
content: This building is in Cow Hollow, less than a block from the Presidio, an expansive city park with views of the Golden Gate Bridge and San Francisco Bay, as well as a golf course, public art installations and a theater. It is a few blocks from Lombard Street and a stretch of Union Street with an Equinox gym, coffee shops and restaurants housed in early 20th-century buildings with ornate facades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Biden Seeks Compensation for Passengers for Flight Delays and Cancellations
description: The Transportation Department said it would propose a rule requiring airlines to provide cash payments to passengers for significant flight disruptions.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced on Monday that it would seek to require airlines to compensate passengers for lengthy flight delays and cancellations that are within their control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Ed Sheeran Lets His Tears Flow on ‘-’
description: Mortality and sorrow bring new depth on the superstar British songwriter’s sixth studio album, pronounced “Subtract.”
content: “There’s beauty when it’s bleak,” Ed Sheeran reminds himself in “Boat,” the opening song on his new album, “-” (pronounced “Subtract”). Mortality loomed around the British musician in 2022, the year he wrote most of the songs on “-,” and it’s reflected in the music: subdued, primarily acoustic and downtempo, and a long way from the big beats and brash productions of its predecessor, “=” (“Equals”) in 2021. Its songs balance between despair and reassurance, barely tilting toward optimism. “If we make it through this year then nothing can break us,” he vows in “No Strings.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin
title: ‘It’s Going to Be a While’: No End in Sight for Hollywood Strike
description: The writers and entertainment companies remain far apart on several key issues, including money, and the standoff could last for months.
content: It’s not just posturing: As screenwriters continue their strike against Hollywood companies, the two sides remain a galaxy apart, portending a potentially long and destructive standoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Suns Owner Sells a Flop as Phoenix Evens Series With Denver
description: Nikola Jokic was issued a technical foul, but wasn’t ejected, when he briefly tangled with the owner Mat Ishbia on the sideline.
content: Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic on Monday was fined $25,000, but not suspended, for making contact with the Suns owner Mat Ishbia while trying to grab a ball away from him in a scuffle at courtside Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: In the end, Trump did not testify at the trial, leaving Carroll to define him on her terms.
description: For the past two weeks, Donald J. Trump’s lawyers have tried to paint E. Jean Carroll’s rape allegations as “unbelievable.” At the same time, they have left open the possibility that Mr. Trump could come to court and deny the accusations himself.
content: For the past two weeks, Donald J. Trump’s lawyers have tried to paint E. Jean Carroll’s rape allegations as “unbelievable.” At the same time, they have left open the possibility that Mr. Trump could come to court and deny the accusations himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: What the End of a Pandemic-Era Health Order Will Mean for the Southern Border
description: Title 42, the rule used to immediately expel migrants, will end this week. U.S. officials expect illegal crossings to increase, placing additional strain on an already overtaxed system.
content: Every day, thousands of migrants cross the southern border of the United States illegally. Fleeing violence, authoritarian states and extreme poverty, they brave the dangerous journey in the hope that once they cross into the United States, they can stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: He Saw ‘Greatness’ in the Lakers When They Were at Their Worst
description: Terrance Burney, an airline employee, has stood outside many Lakers home games this season with encouraging signs — even when the team had the worst record in the N.B.A.
content: You’d have to look closely or you’d miss the homemade sign nailed to a telephone pole outside the Lakers’ practice facility in El Segundo, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry and Photographs By Kirsten Luce
title: A Refugee From Another Time Gets an Eviction Notice
description: A Ukrainian immigrant, 82, has lived in a Manhattan hotel for decades. Now the owners want him out — while earning millions from the city to house others.
content: The travails of many can be lucrative for a few. Take the old Stewart Hotel in Manhattan, which is being used as temporary housing for some of the tens of thousands of migrants who have come north to New York in search of sanctuary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: New Jersey Political Boss to Step Aside After Decades of Power
description: George Norcross III was long considered the state’s most feared and potent unelected politician. His clout had faded after a series of defeats.
content: George Norcross III, New Jersey’s once-powerful Democratic kingmaker, said on Monday that he would step away from politics, acknowledging what most other people in state government had only dared to whisper: that his clout and reach had faded significantly after a series of recent defeats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: At Least 22 Dead After Tourist Boat Capsizes in Southern India
description: Many victims of the tragedy in the state of Kerala were children who were sightseeing on a boat that officials said was overcrowded.
content: At least 22 people, many of them children, were killed after a double-decker tourist boat capsized in the southern Indian state of Kerala on Sunday evening. Rescuers had found eight people with injuries by the next morning, with four of them in critical condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: Deaths of Seniors in Hospital Fire Point to China’s Elder Care Shortfall
description: The country’s supply of nursing home beds has not kept pace with its rapidly aging population, leading some families to seek unlicensed alternatives.
content: BEIJING — The hospital in southern Beijing advertised itself as specializing in vascular tumors, especially benign birthmarks that often appear in infants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: In Debt Limit Talks, Biden and Republicans Start Far Apart
description: As the president prepares to meet with Speaker Kevin McCarthy this week, his budget shares little common ground with spending and tax proposals from House Republicans.
content: President Biden is set to welcome Speaker Kevin McCarthy and other top congressional leaders to the White House on Tuesday for a pivotal round of discussions about the nation’s taxes, spending and debt as a potentially catastrophic government default rapidly approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: How to Help a Teen Who Can’t Sleep
description: Nearly a quarter of adolescents grapple with insomnia. Experts say small habit changes can make a big difference.
content: With packed schedules, school days that kick off at 8 a.m. and the lure of screens, it’s little wonder that many adolescents in the United States don’t get enough sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: Willy Chavarria and Omar Apollo on Faith and Heartbreak
description: Two creative people in two different fields in one wide-ranging conversation. This time: the fashion designer and the “Ivory” musician.
content: Three days after his fall 2023 runway show in February, while on his way to meet Omar Apollo at a photographer’s house in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, the 55-year-old fashion designer Willy Chavarria studied the 25-year-old musician’s Wikipedia page. What Chavarria lacked in detailed knowledge about Apollo’s career, he made up for with an immediate paternal tenderness. Each detail Apollo revealed about himself during their afternoon together — from his recent Grammy nomination for best new artist to his middle name, Apolonio (also the title of his 2020 mixtape) — drew “oohs” and “aahs” from Chavarria, a senior vice president at Calvin Klein and the founder of his own namesake line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What to Know About California’s Boosted Water Allocations
description: For the first time since 2006, the state’s major water conveyance system will deliver all the water it has been asked to supply.
content: California’s reservoirs are filled to the brim. Our snowpack is epic. And, in what feels like a near-miraculous turn of events, less than 8 percent of the state is still considered to be in a drought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The New Surge at the Border
description: The new surge at the U.S.-Mexico border highlights a broader reality about immigration policy.
content: The surge of migrants gathering at the U.S.-Mexico border underscores a point that Democratic Party politicians often try to play down: U.S. border policy has a big effect on how many people try to enter the country illegally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: They Helped New York Bounce Back. Now Their Rents Are Surging.
description: Small businesses outside Manhattan helped fuel the city’s recovery from the pandemic. Their rents have soared, and people of color are bearing the brunt of the increases.
content: A yak-hide championship belt hangs in Yamuna Shrestha’s restaurant in Jackson Heights, Queens, where her momos — pillowy meat-filled dumplings from Nepal — have four times been voted the best in the borough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Adam Goldman, Neelam Bohra and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: After Texas Mall Shooting, Searching for Motive and Grieving for Children
description: As the city of Allen mourns victims, authorities examine racist social media posts that they say belonged to the gunman.
content: Investigators trying to learn why a gunman fatally shot at least eight people at a Texas mall are examining a social media profile, rife with hate-filled rants against women and Black people, that they believe belonged to the gunman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Battery Factories Are Driving Chinese Investment in Europe
description: Although China is investing less in Europe overall, Chinese battery producers are building factories to meet the demands of the region’s growing need for electric vehicles.
content: Battery makers from China are rapidly expanding in Europe, responding to a growing market for electric vehicles while bucking an overall contraction in Chinese investment on the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Webb Telescope Finds a Star Cloaked in 3 Rings of Ruined Worlds
description: Astronomers have gained a new understanding of the chaos that wreathes the bright star Fomalhaut with the help of the powerful space observatory.
content: Fomalhaut, a star just 25 light-years away, is so dazzlingly bright that it blots out the faint light of other stars around it. Stargazers have been enraptured by its secrets for thousands of years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 8, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 8, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Building a Better Colonial Williamsburg
description: Virginia’s reconstructed colonial capital, long criticized as presenting an idealized image of the American Revolution, brings its history into the 21st century.
content: WILLIAMSBURG, Va. — Those who come to Colonial Williamsburg on a nostalgia trip will find some of what they are looking for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Fearing Attacks and Perhaps Unrest, Russia Plans Muted Victory Day
description: The Kremlin will commemorate the Soviet Union’s defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II, but many towns have canceled events on Tuesday.
content: The war in Ukraine has prompted officials across Russia to scale back annual celebrations of Victory Day, the country’s most important national holiday, with more than 20 cities forgoing military parades and organizers calling off a popular nationwide march to honor veterans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Corporate Giants Buy Up Primary Care Practices at Rapid Pace
description: Large health insurers and other companies are especially keen on doctors’ groups that care for patients in private Medicare plans.
content: It’s no surprise that the shortage of primary care doctors — who are critically important to the health of Americans — is getting worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The New A.C. Milan Picks Up Where the Old One Left Off
description: Is there muscle memory to Champions League success? An Italian giant, no longer fallen, is hoping to draw on its own.
content: Stefano Pioli could feel it, even if he could not quite define it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Too Many Older Men Are Still Screened for Prostate Cancer
description: Most have low-risk cancers and rarely benefit from treatment, a new study finds. Actively monitoring the condition is often the best choice.
content: Last summer, Joe Loree made an appointment to see his urologist. He’d occasionally noticed blood in his urine and wanted to have that checked out. His doctor ordered a prostate-specific antigen, or P.S.A., test to measure a protein in his blood that might indicate prostate cancer — or a number of more benign conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Sum 41, Pop-Punk Band of Early 2000s Fame, Says It Will Disband
description: With catchy songs like “Fat Lip” and “In Too Deep,” the Canadian band was part of a pop-punk wave that included Blink-182, Simple Plan, Good Charlotte and others.
content: The band Sum 41 announced on Monday that it was breaking up after 27 years, unleashing a well of nostalgia for the early 2000s, when pop punk seemed ubiquitous on MTV’s “Total Request Live” and in memorable scenes in blockbuster movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: A ban on Russian flags at Victory Day events in Berlin is restored.
description: Russian symbols will not be allowed at commemorations in Berlin marking the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany. Ukrainian flags will be permitted.
content: A Berlin court on Monday upheld a police ban on Russian and Soviet flags and other symbols at this week’s Victory Day celebrations, which commemorate the end of World War II in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
title: ‘Panic’ and Shortages in Parts of Occupied Ukraine Amid Russian Evacuation Orders
description: Running short of food, fuel and cash, and with a Ukrainian counteroffensive imminent, many civilians are defying occupation forces’ directive, unsure where they would go.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — People living in Russian-occupied areas of southern Ukraine described in recent days an atmosphere of confusion, defiance and scarcity, as the occupation authorities ordered tens of thousands of civilians to evacuate in the face of a looming Ukrainian offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Casts Himself as the Trump Beater. Polls Suggest That’s No Sure Thing.
description: While the president argues that he is the one best positioned to stop his predecessor from returning to the White House, surveys indicate that he starts the 2024 race facing enormous challenges.
content: WASHINGTON — Boiled down, President Biden’s argument for running for a second term rather than ceding the ground to the next generation is that he is the Democrat most assured of beating former President Donald J. Trump next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan and Esther Choi
title: Why Do American Diners Have Such a Limited Palate for Textures?
description: Complex taste sensations play a crucial role in food around the world — but have long been shunned stateside.
content: A JELLYFISH TASTES of nothing. Maybe a little salt — a trace of the sea, or of how the creature is packed, once wrested from its natural habitat, for preservation (not of its life but of its viability as food). When its bell is prepared as a raw salad, it tastes only of the ingredients it absorbs: a sluice of soy sauce, sesame oil and black vinegar, scattered garlic, a pinch of sugar. What makes it coveted as a dish in some cultures is the texture, which is nothing like jelly at all. The flesh wobbles but doesn’t deliquesce; instead, it resists, crunching under the teeth, because a jellyfish is almost half made of collagen, the connective tissue whose braided strands run through skin and bone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Should I Wear to My Graduation?
description: With graduation around the corner, a reader wonders how to approach an open-ended dress code.
content: The official graduation uniform — the cap and gown — has its origins in medieval universities, which were designed (see what I did there?) to educate clergymen. Emphasis on the “men.” These religious-leaders-in-training adapted and adopted the robes and hats of the jobs for which they were destined, in part to distinguish themselves from the nonstudents around them. (Also, those old venues of higher learning were cold.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser, Lola Fadulu, Kate Christobek and Karen Zraick
title: In Rape Trial, Jury Must Now Decide if It Believes Carroll or Trump
description: Donald J. Trump never showed up for the trial, nor did his lawyer call witnesses. Their case was simple: The writer E. Jean Carroll had made up her story.
content: As the civil trial over the writer E. Jean Carroll’s allegation that former President Donald J. Trump raped her neared its end, one of her lawyers focused on the man who was missing from the courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Pulitzer Prizes: 2023 Winners List
description: Here is the full list of winners and finalists.
content: The Pulitzer committee honored the A.P. for the work of Mstyslav Chernov, Evgeniy Maloletka, Vasilisa Stepanenko and Lori Hinnant, citing their “courageous reporting from the besieged city of Mariupol that bore witness to the slaughter of civilians in Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Stanford
title: New Butterflies Are Named for Sauron, ‘Lord of the Rings’ Villain
description: The distinctive marks on the newly identified insects resemble the baleful eye of Sauron, the dark lord in J.R.R. Tolkien’s fantasy series.
content: A new genus of butterfly, with dark, eye-like spots on its distinctive orange wings, has been named after Sauron, the arch-villain of J.R.R. Tolkien’s fantasy epic “The Lord of the Rings,” whose gaze lingers malevolently over the lands of Middle-earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: It’s Been Six Weeks, and We Are Fighting Here in Nashville
description: After the Covenant school shooting, our governor may finally listen to the majority of people calling for action on gun violence.
content: NASHVILLE — If you drive through the neighborhoods on my side of town, you’ll see red bows decorating mailboxes and schools and churches and storefronts. Mailbox after mailbox, bow after bow. Even the local liquor store is decorated with a red bow. To visitors, I’m sure it’s a matter for curiosity: Christmas decorations during the green month of May?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Said He’d Veer From Trump on Immigration. The Reality Is More Complicated.
description: Surges of migrants have shaped President Biden’s policies at the border in ways that few of his allies imagined when he was running for president.
content: WASHINGTON — In his final debate with Donald J. Trump on Oct. 22, 2020, Joseph R. Biden Jr., then a candidate, excoriated his rival for radically undermining America’s decades-long tradition of welcoming people who seek asylum at the country’s borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Hiltner
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: King Charles’s Photographer Wanted a ‘Little Piece of Theater’
description: On Saturday, Hugo Burnand had just minutes to take the official portraits of Britain’s newly crowned King Charles III.
content: As King Charles III was crowned in Westminster Abbey on Saturday, Hugo Burnand, a British photographer, waited in Buckingham Palace’s glittering Throne Room for the most important moment of his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson and Adam Riding
title: In Parched Arizona, the Produce Gardens Bloom
description: Gardeners and small farmers are growing food with minimal water, in ways large and small that could help the Southwest survive an epochal drought.
content: Kim Elle had never grown anything more complicated than houseplants when she and her husband moved from Georgia to suburban Phoenix in 2021. Faced with a sizable yard in a well-groomed subdivision, she turned to gardening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Are Republicans Willing to Raise the Debt Ceiling?
description: President Biden is offering a reasonable path to resolve the latest debt ceiling standoff. Are Republicans willing to take it?
content: President Biden is offering congressional Republicans a reasonable path to resolve the standoff over raising the federal debt ceiling. He has rightly insisted the ceiling itself must be raised without conditions, so the government can meet the obligations it already has incurred, while expressing a willingness to separately negotiate measures to slow the growth of the federal debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna-Lisa Cohen
title: I’m Going to Spoil Your Favorite TV Show
description: Everyone gets mad about spoilers. But science suggests our concern about spoilers ruining our enjoyment of stories is overblown.
content: In this divisive era, when there are so few things we all still agree on, one point of basic civility stands unchallenged: You don’t mention the ending of a television show or movie if the person you’re talking with hasn’t seen it yet. It’s just basic human decency. Premature plot revelations are so far out of bounds that their name alone stands as a warning: spoilers. (On that note and before we go any further: Spoilers ahead.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Financial Stability Experts at the Fed Turn a Wary Eye on Commercial Real Estate
description: A financial stability report from the Federal Reserve flagged concerns tied to rising interest rates, including in commercial real estate.
content: Federal Reserve financial stability experts are on the lookout for weaknesses after a year of rising interest rates — and as they survey the potential risks confronting the system, they are increasingly watching office loans and other commercial real estate borrowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: A Philosopher and a Slaver, but No Longer a Name on a Library
description: No one disputes that George Berkeley was among Ireland’s greatest thinkers, but he was also an unapologetic slaver. Now, Trinity College Dublin is taking his name off one of its buildings.
content: Trinity College Dublin has decided to seek a new name for its central library, the Berkeley, after concluding that the alumnus it honors, the 18th-century philosopher George Berkeley, owned slaves in colonial Rhode Island and wrote pamphlets supportive of slavery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Pfeiffer
title: If I Were Sitting in the White House, This Is What Would Scare Me About Kevin McCarthy
description: The 2023 debt ceiling crisis seems much more dangerous than the ones Obama dealt with when I worked in the West Wing.
content: When President Biden meets with congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday, he will most likely reiterate his position that Congress should pass a bill lifting the debt ceiling without negotiations or conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: In 1963, Avedon Took a Picture That Shed Light on America
description: William Casby, who had been enslaved, was 106 when a famous photographer asked him to sit for a photo.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll look at a Richard Avedon photograph that traced a shameful arc in the nation’s history in a very personal way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Racetracks, Parks, Offices: A Frantic Search for Migrant Housing
description: New York City officials are casting a wide net as they scramble to house the influx of migrants. The Flatiron Building said no.
content: When the real estate industry looks at the Flatiron Building, they see an internationally famous 22-story skyscraper that has sat mostly empty for four years, its value dropping in the pandemic-driven collapse of the commercial office market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Father-Son Duo in Alabama Wins Pulitzer, Bucking Headwinds in Local News
description: John Archibald, who has been a journalist in Birmingham, Ala., for years, was anxious about his son Ramsey’s decision to go into journalism. He needn’t have worried.
content: One of the best moments in John Archibald’s life came in 2018, when he won a Pulitzer Prize for columns published by Alabama Media Group, the largest news publisher in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Debt-Ceiling Déjà Vu Worries Wall Street
description: The last crisis, in 2011, led to a credit downgrade that sank stocks. This time, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has warned of a “financial catastrophe.”
content: If Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is correct, there are just a few precious weeks remaining for Congress and the White House to reach a debt-limit accord and avoid “an economic and financial catastrophe.” That makes Tuesday’s meeting between President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy all the more pivotal as a deadline looms for the U.S. to potentially run out of cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman and Sasha Arutyunova
title: For This Glass Blower, Art Is a Full-Body Sport
description: The intense process of working with glass, Deborah Czeresko says, means “moving all the time.”
content: Art of Craft is a series about specialists whose work rises to the level of art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Season 4, Episode 7 Recap: The Scorpion and the Scorpion
description: This week, the Roys throw the election eve party they inherited from Logan and as always, they arrive with their own discrete agendas.
content: This “Succession” season’s premiere episode ended with Tom and Shiv lying together in bed, bitterly angry but still holding hands. In the weeks since, the couple has been flirting more openly (and bizarrely), trying to figure out if perhaps they are each broken in just the right way that their jagged pieces can fit back together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Long Play Rises to the Top of New York Classical Music Festivals
description: This weekend of concerts, organized by Bang on a Can, has quickly but assertively ascended to the rank of destination event.
content: Long Play has been around only since last year, but it is already the most important classical music festival in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: El Bulli’s Explores Gastronomy in an Expansive Series of Books
description: Read the El Bulli Foundation’s newest books on wine, pick up a Sweeney Todd apron and more food news.
content: In 2011 the chef Ferran Adrià stepped back and closed his avant-garde restaurant, El Bulli, to pursue a foundation dedicated to food ideas. The El Bulli Foundation, which replaced his restaurant, is now publishing more than 20 books about many aspects of gastronomy. It’s part of the Bullipedia project, encyclopedic surveys and analyses written by teams of experts. There are eight volumes of intensely‌ detailed books on wine, Bullipedia Wine Sapiens; the first two, “Contextualizaton and Viticulture” and “Vinification and Classifications,” have been translated from Spanish into English — subsidized by Juvé & Camps, a venerable cava producer — and are now available in the United States. “We examined many books on wine, even wine atlases, but found none that took our encyclopedic approach,” Mr. Adrià said. The books are designed for professionals and gastronomes, especially for those who are engaged in and appreciate fine-dining, which Mr. Adrià contends is thriving. With Hubbell precision, the books examine the history, evolution, production, categorization, serving and appreciation of good wine, illustrating the material with close-ups of ripening berries, pruning methods, climate maps, bottling and more in the first two books’ nearly 1,200 pages. Mr. Adrià and Ferran Centelles, the sommelier who covers the beverage side of the project, say they have made discoveries, like the first printed wine list from 1804. It is all, however, seen through a Western lens; the foundation’s definition of fine dining ‌is limited — it does not invite Asian cuisines to the table, for example. “We can only be experts in Western culture,” Mr. Adrià said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The New Definitive Biography of Martin Luther King Jr.
description: “King: A Life,” by Jonathan Eig, is the first comprehensive account of the civil rights icon in decades.
content: Growing up, he was called Little Mike, after his father, the Baptist minister Michael King. Later he sometimes went by M.L. Only in college did he drop his first name and began to introduce himself as Martin Luther King Jr. This was after his father visited Germany and, inspired by accounts of the reform-minded 16th-century friar Martin Luther, adopted his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Morgan Wallen’s ‘One Thing at a Time’ Notches a 9th Week at No. 1
description: The country superstar held off a release from the K-pop group Seventeen to maintain his streak atop the Billboard 200. Ed Sheeran will challenge him next week.
content: Morgan Wallen, the country superstar who dominates streaming, holds the No. 1 spot on the Billboard album chart for a ninth consecutive week, fending off a formidable challenge from the K-pop group Seventeen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: The Trump Rape Trial Enters its Final Phase
description: Also, authorities are looking for a motive in a Texas shooting. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Lawyers delivered closing arguments today in E. Jean Carroll’s lawsuit accusing Donald Trump of battery and defamation. The jury in Manhattan will begin deliberating tomorrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: To Make Art She Believed In, a Woman Needed to Live on Her Own
description: An artist who enjoys living on the edge finds herself in a Bushwick apartment after breaking up with her partner of eight years.
content: When Roxana Kadyrova first moved to New York at age 24 nearly a decade ago, she felt an overwhelming sense of loneliness. Coming from Moscow, she’d always enjoyed the thrill of being in a new place all on her own, but this time was different. Her English wasn’t very strong then, so language became another barrier to connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: The Women Who Are Giving Dating Apps the Summer Off
description: Summer is the season where romantic encounters heat up. Some singles are logging off to see what’s out there.
content: Divai Brown, a 39-year-old lawyer from Harlem, has lived in Dublin for about 15 months, working in financial regulations, and loves it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Dispassionate Traumas and Choral Dream Songs
description: Juliana May’s “Family Happiness” at Abrons Arts Center at times feels like a punishing exercise.
content: What’s wrong with these people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Price to Plug Old Wells in Gulf of Mexico? $30 Billion, Study Says.
description: There are roughly 14,000 old, unplugged wells in the gulf that are at risk of springing leaks or causing environmental damage, researchers found.
content: Ever since the first offshore platforms went up off Louisiana 85 years ago, the Gulf of Mexico has been an oil and gas juggernaut. But decades of drilling has left behind more than 14,000 old, unplugged wells at risk of springing dangerous leaks and spills that may cost more than $30 billion to plug, a new study has found. Nonproducing wells that haven’t been plugged now outnumber active wells in the gulf, the study says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Ronald Steel, Critic of American Cold War Policies, Dies at 92
description: In essays and books. he saw the U.S. postwar era as a series of misadventures spawning unwise wars. He also wrote the definitive biography of the journalist Walter Lippmann.
content: Ronald Steel, a historian who derided America’s Cold War foreign policies as a succession of misguided adventures and wrote a definitive biography of Walter Lippmann, the dean of 20th-century foreign policy realism, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin J. Delaney
title: Bringing A.I. Tools to the Workplace Requires a Delicate Balance
description: Move too slowly, and risk getting left behind. Move too quickly, and neither the staff nor the technology may be ready.
content: By midyear, all of Morgan Stanley’s thousands of wealth advisers are expected to have access to a new artificial-intelligence-powered chat tool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Here’s How Wall Street Is Preparing for a U.S. Debt Default
description: There are contingency plans in place, but damage would be inevitable.
content: Last week I spoke with two people on Wall Street who are planning what to do in case Congress and the White House can’t reach a deal on raising or suspending the debt ceiling. They told me that it’s not clear how well the contingency plan for a default by the federal government would work, because it’s never been tested. Even if it did work exactly as conceived, they said, a default would still damage the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Landau and Ben Klemens
title: Overlooked No More: James Sakoda, Whose Wartime Internment Inspired a Social Science Tool
description: After documenting his experience in Japanese American internment camps, Sakoda helped bring the study of human behavior to the computer age.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: Comedy Is in Their (Identical) DNA
description: Annabel and Sabina Meschke, twin sister comedians, haul around a truck full of pennies in a new short film. Once a month, they audition potential triplets.
content: The twins took the stage in matching red cowboy boots. On a recent Wednesday night in Brooklyn — the kind of chilly, misty night made for staying in — about 200 people had come out to see them. The audience at Littlefield, a performance space in Gowanus, sipped cocktails through Twizzlers and ate tacos in folding chairs, hugging and laughing as they settled in for a night of comedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin P. Russell
title: The Making of a New M.L.K. Biography: A Q. & A. With the Author, Jonathan Eig
description: New archival material and a narrowing window in which to speak to people who knew Martin Luther King, Jr. fueled the work, said the author.
content: Having written about Muhammad Ali, Al Capone, Jackie Robinson and other touchstones of the American imagination, Jonathan Eig says he recognizes a common trait in the disparate personalities he’s explored.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: When Chatbots ‘Hallucinate’
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 8, 2023.
content: “If you don’t know an answer to a question already, I would not give the question to one of these systems.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Virginia Teenager Dies After He Is Buried in Sand From Dune Collapse
description: The 17-year-old was trapped under several feet of sand at Cape Hatteras National Seashore in North Carolina, the National Park Service said. He was in a back-dune area on Hatteras Island.
content: A teenager from Chesapeake, Va., died after he was buried in several feet of sand on Saturday inside a hole that had been dug in a back-dune area at Cape Hatteras National Seashore in North Carolina, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: China’s Foreign Minister Meets U.S. Envoy and Urges Washington to Reflect
description: The meeting was one of the highest-level engagements between American and Chinese officials since the downing of a suspected Chinese spy balloon in February.
content: China’s foreign minister, Qin Gang, met with the American ambassador to China in Beijing on Monday in a possible hint at a thaw in relations between the two powers after months of growing tension.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kylian Mbappé Is Coming for It All

title: GWS-Judy-Blume

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Name the Subjects of These Landmark Biographies?
description: Try this short quiz to see how much you know about these well-documented lives — and maybe add a few titles to your reading list.
content: Try this short quiz to see how much you know about these well-documented lives — and maybe add a few titles to your reading list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ashley Wu
title: We Hit the Debt Limit. What Happens Now?
description: Lawmakers will need to reach a bipartisan agreement to lift the debt limit. The longer it takes, the more turmoil there could be for the United States and the global economy.
content: Lawmakers will need to reach a bipartisan agreement to lift the debt limit. The longer it takes, the more turmoil there could be for the United States and the global economy.

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz and Alicia Parlapiano
title: What Would the G.O.P. Plan Actually Do to the Budget?
description: The plan declines to make choices on cuts, and with large categories exempted by leadership, that may make implementing the bill even harder than passing it.
content: The plan declines to make choices on cuts, and with large categories exempted by leadership, that may make implementing the bill even harder than passing it.

author: By Storyful
title: Mourners Honor Victims of Texas Mall Shooting
description: Crowds gathered outside a mall in Allen, Texas, where a gunman opened fire on shoppers and killed at least eight people.
content: Crowds gathered outside a mall in Allen, Texas, where a gunman opened fire on shoppers and killed at least eight people.
source.name: The New York Times
